File.Title: Parasagittal Organization of the Rat Cerebellar Cortex: Direct Correlation Between Antigenic Purkinje Cell Bands Revealed by mabQll3 and the Organization of the Olivocerebellar Projection
File.Authors: CLAUDE GRAVEL, LEONARD M. EISENMAN, RACHEL SASSEVILLE, AND RICHARD HAWKES

Abstract.S: The Purkinje cells of the cerebellar cortex and the cortical afferent and efferent projections are organized into parallel parasagittal zones.
The parasagittal organization is clearly revealed by immunocytochemistry with a monoclonal antibody, mabQ113.

The mabQl13 antigen is confined to a subset of Purkinje cells that are clustered together to form an elaborate, highly reproducible pattern of bands and patches, interspersed with similar mabQ113 - regions.
The mabQ113 + territories have been classified into seven parasagittal bands (P1 +-P7 +) in each hemicerebellum.
The degree of correspondence between the compartments revealed by the anterograde labeling of the olivocerebellar projection and by mabQ113 immunocytochemistry has been explored in the adult rat.
Horseradish peroxide-wheat germ agglutinin conjugate was injected as an anterograde tracer into the inferior olivary complex.
When the injection site did not encompass all the olive, an incomplete, patchy labeling of the molecular layer was seen in the cerebellar cortex.
Labeled zones of the molecular Iaycr were interrupted by unIabeled regions to give a pattern of parasagittal cortical bands.
The positions of these bands were compared with the distribution of lhe niabQll3 + antigenic bands as seen on the two adjacent sections.
Labeled climbing fibers were found to terminate on both mabQll3 + and mabQ113 - Purkinje cell zones.
The mabQl13 clmabQ113 - boundaries and the bands of climbing fibers seen by using the anterogade tracer typically coincide.
The one consistent exception is the midline band of mabQ113 + Purkinje cells, P1+.

The normal olivocerebellar projection is exclusively contralateral and the climbing fiber projection to the paramedian vermis splits PI + down the middle, implying that it consists of two adjacent mabQ113+ bands not separated by mabQll3 -territory.
It is likely that the climbing fiber projection to the cerebellar cortex and the distribution of the two Purkinje cell phenotypes share a common compartmental organization.

Introduction.S: robiologie, Pavillon Notre-Dame, 2075 Ave de Vitre, Quebec, P.Q., Canada GlJ 124.
The mammalian cerebeller cortex is organized into parasagittal zones.
This proposal is supported by more than forty years of research, based at first on anatomical and electrophysiological methods, and bolstered more recently by histochemistry and immunocytochemistry.

A parasagittal zonation was shown first for the Purkinje cell efferent projection to the cerebellar nuclei and the lateral vestibular nuclei (eg., Jansen and Brodal, '40,'42; Chambers and Sprague, '55a,b; Courville and Diakiw, '76; Voogd and Bigare, '80; Haines et al., '82), and subsequently, a similar afferent parcellation was shown to be present in some mossy fiber pathways (Voogd, '69; Scheibel, '77; Chan-Palay et al., '77; Yaginuma and Matsushita, '86) and in the climbing fiber projection from the inferior olives (Voogd, '64,'67,'69; Oscarsson, '69,'80; Oscarsson and Sjolund, '77; Van Gilder and O'Leary, '70; Armstrong et al., '74,'82; Groenewegen and Voogd, '77; Groenewegen et al., '79; Courville, '75; Courville and Faraco-Cantin, '78; Brodal et al., '75; Brodal, '76,'80; Beyerl et al., '82; Eisenman, '81,'84; Eisenman et al., '83).

In the rat, incomplete filling of an inferior olive with anterograde tracer results in the labeling of parasagittally organized bands of climbing fibers in the molecular layer of the contralateral cerebellar cortex (Armstrong et al., '82; Campbell and Armstrong, '83, Sotelo et al., '84).
Molecular correlates of a parasagittal organization within the cerebellar cortex have also been demonstrated.

Scott ('63,'64) and others (e.g., Marani, ,821, by using histochemical techniques, localized the enzyme 5'-nucleotidase to parasagittal bands in the molecular layer of the mouse and rat cerebellar cortex (but not in the cat; see Marani and Voogd, '77).

Parasagittal heterogeneity of acetylcholinesterase activity has also been demonstrated histochemically in the cerebellar cortex of young and adult cats (Ramon-Moliner, '72; Marani and Voogd, '77; Marani, '82; Brown and Graybiel, '83).
The staining is concentrated in the molecular layer and appears as positive and negative parasagittal zones.

Although this staining pattern is not found in the rat and mouse, preliminary evidence suggests that a similar acetylcholinesterase segregation can be demonstrated in the monkey (Ingram et al., 85; Hess and Voogd, '86).
This pattern may be related to the differential acetylcholinesterase staining pattern demonstrated in the IOC (Marani et al., '77).
Immunohistochemical methods have also been brought to bear on the question of cerebellar heterogeneity.

By using antibodies against cysteine-sulfinic acid decarboxylase, Chan-Palay et al. ('82) demonstrated differential immunostaining of Purkinje, stellate, basket, and Eolgi cells and their processes in the rat, rabbit, and mouse.
The immunoreactive cells form parasagittal microzones separated by nonimmunoreactive interzones.

Antigenic heterogeneity in the Purkinje cell population is also seen when the rat, mouse, or monkey tissue is processed with an antibody raised against synthetic porcine motilin (Chan-Palay et al., '81; Nilaver et al., '82) and has also been reported for an antibody raised against glutamic acid decarboxylase (ChanPalay et al., '81).

Combined used of these antibodies has shown on simple segregation of epitopes, some Purkinje cells reacting only with one or other antibody, some reacting with both, and yet others reacting with neither.
More recently, Ingram et al. ('85) described the monoclonal antibody B1 that revealed broad bands of positively and negatively reactive Purkinje cells in the monkey cerebellar cortex.
Some other cerebellar neurons also bear the epitope.
The B1 bands do not seem to codistribute with the motilin, glutamic acid decarboxylase, or taurine bands, nor do they correspond to the acetylcholinesterase staining pattern (Ingram et al., '85).
Another, probably different, pattern of bands and patches is revealed by monoclonal antibody mabQ155 (Hawkes et al., '85).
MabQ155 recognizes an epitope associated with all the major synaptic types of the rat and mouse cerebellar cortex.

Despite its broad cellular distribution in the mouse cerebellar cortex, mabQ 155-immunocytochemistry reveals parasagittal zones of alternating high and low reactivity that include both the granular layer and the molecular layer.
Together, these studies are highly suggestive of widespread chemical heterogeneity in the cerebellar cortex, particularly among the Purkinje cell population.
Perhaps the clearest demonstration of this is seen with the monoclonal antibody mabQ113 (Hawkes et al., '85; Plioplys et al., '85; Hawkes and Leclerc, '86,'87).
The distribution of the mabQll3 epitope in the cerebellar cortex is intriguing because it is strictly confined to a subset of Purkinje cells.
Immunoreactivity is found throughout the cytoplasm of the immunopositive cells, including dendritic spines and dendrites, the somata, the axons, and the axon collaterals.

Antigen-bearing Purkinje cells are arranged into highly symmetrical parasagittal bands extending throughout the anteroposterior extent of the cerebellum in a pattern reproducible from animal to animal (Hawkes et al., '85; Hawkes and Leclerc, '87).

These data provide multiple independent maps of cerebellar organization, but few attempts have been made to compare, collate, and synthesize the schemata obtained by using different experimental methods (e.g., Hess and Voogd, '86).

In particular, the question remains open as to whether the parasagittal organization of different afferent fibers and of various intrinsic biochemical markers reflects a common structural plan, or whether each is a unique representation in its own right.

In addition to the difficulty inherent in comparing data collected by using different methodologies, a second problem is that these data have been collected in many different species, thus further confounding attempts at synthesis.

To address this problem, in this paper we compare the band pattern produced in the cerebellar cortex following injection of wheat germ agglutinin-horseradish peroxidase complex CWGA-HRP) into the inferior olive with the immunocytochemical staining pattern obtained with the mabQll3 antibody.
Some of these results appeared previously in abstract form (Gravel et al., '86).

Methods.S: Antemgrade labeling with wheat germ agglutininhorseradish peroxidase conjugate
Adult Sprague Dawley rats were used in all experiments.
The animals were anesthetized with an intramuscular injection of ketamine hydrochloride (45 mgkg) containing 1% acepromazine.
Microinjections of WGA-HRP conjugate were placed into the IOC via a ventral retropharyngeal a p proach.
Tracer was injected via a 1-pl Hamilton syringe to which a glass micropipette (tip diameter 50-75 pm} was attached.

After a survival time of 24 hours, the animal was sacrificed with an overdose of Nembutal and perfused through the heart with saline followed by a fixative containing 4% paraformaldehyde and 0.2% glutaraldehyde in phosphate buffer (pH 7.4).
Immediately after perfusion the brain was removed, postfixed for a few hours in the formaldehyde alone, and then placed in buffer overnight at 4Â°C.
The next day the brain was shipped by express mail from Philadelphia to Quebec for processing to reveal the anterograde transport of tracer and the bands of antigenic Purkinje cells.
Horizontal or frontal sections of cerebellum were cut at 50 pm on a freezing-stage microtome.
Every third section was incubated overnight at room temperature with constant agitation in mabQll3-containing culture medium diluted 1:32 in 10% decomplemented normal horse serum.

Then, after three 10-minute rinses in a 0.1 M phosphatebuffered 0.9% saline solution (PBS), the sections were incubated for 2 hours in peroxidase-conjugated rabbit antimouse immunoglobulins (Dako, Denmark) diluted 1:lOO in 10% normal horse serum.

Following 3 additional rinses in PBS, the reaction sites were revealed by using 4-chloro-lnaphthol as chromogen (Hawkes et al., '82) and the sections mounted on slides in a 90% glycerol, 10% PBS solution.

The anterogradely transported peroxidase activity is too weak to be revealed with 4-chloro-1-naphthol, and thus there is no confusion between Purkinje cell immunoreactivity and climbing fiber labeling.

The other sections were processed for peroxidase histochemistry with tetramethylbenzidine (TMB) as the chromogen (Mesulam, '821, then dehydrated through graded ethanol solutions and mounted in Permount (Fisher, Inc.).
Transverse sections of the brainstem were cut at 50 pm between the caudal limit of the pons and the rostra1 limit of the IOC (Paxinos and Watson, '82).
Every third section was collected, the injection site was revealed by using tetramethylbenzidine, and the sections counterstained with either neutral red or cresyl violet.

Results.S: RESULTS
MabQ113 immunocytochemical staining

On Western blots of the rat cerebellar cortex, monoclonal antibody Q113 (mabQ113) recognizes an epitope restricted to a single polypeptide of apparent molecular weight 120 Kdaltons (Hawkes et al., '85).
The laminar distribution of the mabQ113 epitope in the cerebellar cortex as revealed by peroxidase immunocytochemistry is illustrated in Figure 1A , B .

Peroxidase reaction product is confined exclusively to the Purkinje cells, where it is distributed throughout the cell from the axon and axon collaterals to the somata, the dendrites, and the dendritic spines.
No other cell types in the cerebcllum, neuronal or glial, are immunoreactive (for other brain regions, see Plioplys and Hawkes, '86).
Details of the subcellular distribution will be presented elsewhere (Leclerc et al., in preparation).

The most interesting feature of the mabQ113 epitope is its restricted distribution among the Purkinje cell population; the epitope is expressed in only a subset, as a whole about one-third, of the cells (Hawkes and Leclerc, '87).

The immunoreactive Purkinje cells ( mabQl13 + ) are clustered together to form a family of parasagittal bands running roughly rostrocaudally throughout the cerebellar cortex , interposed by similar bands of mabQll3cells ( Fig . 2A ) .
The detailed description of the immunocytochemical banding pattern is provided elsewhere (Hawkes and Leclerc, '87).

Briefly, the parasagittal zonation revealed by mabQ113 is symmetrical about the midline and is reproducible from individual to individual both in the number and general arrangement of the bands and in much of the fine detail.
By calling bands of mabQ113 + cells P + and mabQ113 - cells P-, we have defined a midline band (P1+) and six or seven lateral P+ bands on each side (P2+ to P7 +(P8 + ); Fig. 2B).
In the vermis the bands ( P1 + , P2 + , P3 + ) are continuous from lobule to lobule .
In general , the bands tend to become weaker and less well defined as they pass into the anterior lobe .

Careful observation of the midline P1 + band reveals that the axons issuing from the mabQll3 + Purkinje cells segregate into two fascicles divided by the anatomical midline , and enter uncrossed in the white matter within the left and right sides of the cerebellum , respectively ( Fig . 3A ) .
On this basis, the P1+ band is best described as two parallel, confluent P+ bands, not separated by a negative (P-) Purkinje cell zone.

The mabQ113 + staining in the hemispheres is also consistent with a rather convoluted parasagittal zonation ( P4 + , P5 i , P6 + , P7 + ) , but a checkerboard arrangement of Purkinje cell clusters is at least as plausible .
The immunoreactivity diminishes in the more lateral regions of the hemispheres , making the presence of an extreme lateral P8 + uncertain .
Additional subbands of P4 + and P5 + ( called P4b + and P5a + , respectively ) are seen in the crus 2.

In addition to these well-ordered and highly reproducible bands or mabQ113 + cells, satellite bands are also common; these are defined as narrow, positively immunoreactive bands of Purkinje cells, often only one cell in width, lying adjacent to one of the major bands (Fig. 3B).
In contrast to the P+ bands, satellite bands are not reproducible from individual to individual nor are they necessarily bilaterally symmetrical.
They do, however, extend substantially in the dorsoventral plane and thus are not simply occasional mabQ113s Purkinje cells isolated within mabQ113territory.

These satellite bands, together with possible variations in the depth and tilt of the plane of section and with differences in the extent of foliation, require that olivocerebellar projection bands and the mabQ113 imrnunocytochemical banding pattern be compared directly in each individual instead of referring to an idealized map of the epitope distribution.
Anterograde labeling of the olivocerebellar projection

TTE.S: Either large ( nominally 30 nl ) or small ( nominally 10 nl ) injections of WGA - HRP conjugate were placed in the right JOC of experimental animals via a retropharyngeal approach ( Chan - Palay et al . , 77 ) .
Typically , small injections resulted in a labeling of olivary cells restricted mainly to the side of the injection , whereas labeling from a large injection spans the two IOC to varying extents .

Figure 4A , B shows portions of typical injection sites , photographed at a similar rostrocaudal level ( approximately 13 mm caudal from the bregma ; Paxinos and Watson , 82 ) , resulting from small ( Fig . 4A ) or large ( Fig . 4B ) tracer injections .

It can be seen that thc peroxidase reaction product is not restricted to the IOC but also extends into adjacent regions , principally the reticular formation dorsomedially and dorsolaterally and the pyramids ventromedially .
The use of TMB may result in the overestimation of the injection site due to the difference between virtual and effective injection sites (Mesulam, 82).
Axons from the labeled neurons of one IOC cross the olivary commissure and spread through the contralateral IOC .
They then form a thin bundle that follows a rostral and dorsal path and ascends to the cerebellum via the inferior cerebellar peduncle .
In the cerebellum , they terminate as climbing fibers upon the Purkinje cell primary dendrites .
Labeled collateral axons are also seen entering the cerebellar nuclei .

Thus , the uptake and subsequent anterograde transport of WGA - HRP by olivary cells result in the accumulation of tracer in the molecular layer of the cerebellar cortex , and to a lesser extent also in the cerebellar nuclei .

Results.S: Examination of the sections at higher magnification reveals that the labeling consists of closely spaced, discrete lines of TMB crystals running along the Purkinje cell dendritic arbors from the Purkinje cell layer toward the pial surface (Fig. 5).
It should be emphasized here that it is not the present intention to analyze the detailed topography of the olivocerebellar prqjectioln with respect to Purkinje cell compartmentation.
Rather, we wish to establish whether such a comparison is at all worthwhile.
If the Purkinje cell distribution and the olivocerebellar projection are unlinked, a topographical comparison may be of little value-we know already that both share broadly similar organizations.

On the other hand, if the olivocerebellar projection and the Purkinje cell conipartments share a common parasagittal ground plan-and it is argued below that this is indeed the case-then this has important functional and developmental implications.
With this in mind , WGA - HRP was injected into the IOC in order to generate bands of anterogradely labeled climbing fibers that could be compared with the mabQ113 + Purkinje cell distribution .
Relatively large injection sites were employed that reliahly produce labeled bands of climbing fibers but that are largely unsuitable for determining the details of the topography .
Virtual injection sites were studied in neutral red counterstained sections and the distribution of peroxidase activity within the IOC was mapped onto the rat IOC schema of Gwyn et al. ( 77).
Injection sites for the animals described explicitly in the results are described below.

TTE.S: Case No . 22% The center of the injection site in rat no . 227 is situated in the caudal portion of the right MAO , about 600 km from the caudal pole of the complex, where the dorsal cap ( dc ) separates from the main portion of the medial accessory olive ( MAO ) ( Fig . 6 ) .
At around this level , the virtual injection site is very large and reaction product is found throughout the right side and most of the left side of the 10.
Only the most lateral portion of the left MA0 is completely devoid of TMB deposits.

The extent of the territory covered by reaction product narrows and becomes restricted to the more medial regions more rostrally , but it still covers parts of the right and left olives up to the most rostral extent of the principal olive ( PO ) at about 2,400 km from the caudal pole .

Consistent with the large virtual injection site , the staining in the cerebellar cortex is extensive and bilateral , and reaction product is present throughout the whole dorsoventral extent of the cerebellum ( the vermis is illustrated ; see Figs . 8,9,10 ) .
The hemicerebellum contralateral to the injection site is more completely and more heavily labeled than its ipsilateral counterpart .
However , both sides still show regions where reaction product is scarce or absent .
For example , in the vermis a clearcut boundary in staining intensity is seen running rostrocaudally through all lobules .

This boundary bisects the vermis and is presumed to be the anatomical midline on the basis of both its central position and its exact alignment with the raphe frequently seen medially in or between lobules VIII to X.
Such a midline demarcation was consistently observed in all experimental animals ( except for animal no . 234, see below ) in which the virtual injection site spanned the rnidline .

In the vermis of case no . 227, there is a band that is strongly labeled by anterograde transport , located adjacent to the midline on the right side , extending from lobule I11 to the rostral face of lobules VI - VII .
Several less complete parasagittal vermal bands, positive and negative, are also seen on this same section.

In the hemispheres , there are also several bands or patches of various extents , seen either as negative zones within an HRP - reactive background or as anterograde labeled climbing fibers in an otherwise unreactive molecular layer .
Ipsilateral (right) to the injection site, the most lateral portions of crus 1 and crus 2 are devoid of reaction product.

Results.S: Case no. 228.

TTE.S: The center of the injection site in animal no. 228 is situated at about 1,100 pm from the caudal pole of the IOC.
The virtual injection site is very large at this level and reaction product can be found in all the right olive , in the left MAO , and the medial fourth of the left DAO ( Fig . 6 ) .
TMB deposits can be seen throughout the rostrocaudal extent of the right olive but become scarcer in the more lateral regions as one approaches the rostral limit of the complex .

However , the presence of weakly labeled stretches of molecular layer in the left half of the cerebellum ( see Fig . 9B ) suggests that not all olivary cells froin the right olive have tansported the tracer .
Caudally in the left olive , the staining is restricted to more medial regions and in the caudal one - fifth of the MAO , no reaction product is observed over subnucleus a .
Rostrally , reaction product is present in the medial fourth of the DAO , the medial half of the PO , and throughout the MAO .
On horizontal sections , stained climbing fibers are seen over the whole dorsoventral extent of the cerebellum ; the staining is bilateral but more extensive in the left ( contralateral ) side .
In the more dorsal regions , almost of the cerebellar cortex contains reaction product , but a few bands of relatively weaker intensity are visible on both sides .

Additional weakly labeled zones appear more ventrally , especially in the anterior lobe , and 5 mm interaural ( Paxinos and Watson , ' 82 ) only parts of crus I1 show staining in the right hemisphere .

Results.S: Case no. 234.

TTE.S: In animal no . 234, the injection site is centered in the rostral half of the right olive , at about 200 pm from the caudal pole of the complex ( Fig . 6 ) .

Again , the virtual injection site is very large at this level and encompasses all of the right olive and most of the left one , with only the lateral half of the DAO completely free of TMB deposils .
Although reaction product is scarcer toward the caudal pole , deposits are still found over all the right olive and most of the left one save the lateral DAO .
In the cerebellar cortex , the staining is bilateral and covers most of the dorsoventral extent of the cerebellum , but is much more extensive in the anterior lobe .
Parasagittal bands of weak and strong reactivities are found in both sides (see Fig. 9C).
The staining is more extensive in the hemispheres ( especially the left one ) than in the vermis .

Results.S: Case no. 274.

TTE.S: The center of the injection through the IOC of rat no . 274 is situated in the right PO , at the level in the frontal plane at which it reaches its maximum mediolateral extent , about 2,000 pm from the caudal pole of the complex ( Fig . 7 ) .
At this level , reaction product is also found in the MAO , the dorsomedial cell column ( dmcc ) , and the medial portion of the DAO .
There is no reaction product in any subdivision of the left olive .

In the molecular layer of the cerebellum , climbing fiber labeling is strictly contralateral to the injection site , and takes the form of patches or bands in crus 1 and crus 2 of the left hemisphere ( for illustrated details , see Fig . 13 ) .
The molecular layer labeling in the cerebellar cortex extends rostrocaudally over about 1,600 Fm .
The vermis is unlabeled.

Results.S: Case rw. 275.

TTE.S: In animal no . 275, the injection site is centered at the same rostrocaudal level as for animal no . 274 , that is , in the right olive at about 2,000 pm from the caudal pole of the complex .
However , the virtual injection site is larger in this case and encroaches into the left olive ( Fig . 5 ) .

At this level , reaction product is found over most of the right olive with only the most lateral third of the DAO free of reaction product , and in the left olive covers most of the MAO , the dmcc , and a small medial portion of the PO .
The reactive site becomes narrower caudally , and from about 1,100 pm from the caudal pole no reaction product is found in any subdivision of the left olive .
In the right olive , the virtual injection site becomes restricted to the lateral portion of the MA0 and medial portion of DAO in the caudal half of the complex .
From about 600 pm from the caudal pole, the olive is free of reaction product.
Rostrally , TMB deposits are found over most of the right olive and in 228 - A0 A
t.he MA0 and dmcc of the left olive.
In the cerebellar cortex , the vermis is almost devoid of reaction product and labeled climbing fiber bands or patches appear in the paravermal area and hemispheres on both sides ( see Fig . 12 ) .
The staining is more intense on the left side and is mainly concentrated in crus I1 and paramedian lobules .

Results.S: Variations in the location and size of the injection sites are by far the most important contributor to interindividual differences when comparing the olivocerebellar banding pattern following tracer injections in the IOC.

Clearly, however, the accuracy of comparisons of this kind is inherently limited in the absence of reproducible (or better, individualized) landmarks, especially at the level of the cerebellar cortex.

Figure 9A - C shows the pattern of anterogradely labeled climbing fibers in horizontal sections from the posterior vermis ( lobules VIII - IX ) of 3 different animals that had received WGA - HRP tracer injections in the IOC .
In all 3, the virtual injection site included parts of both olives but is centered at a differcnt rostrocaudal level in the IOC (shown in Fig. 6).
Correspondingly, the cortical staining is bilateral and takcs the form of parasagittal bands distributed about the midline.

The extent of labeling in the molecular layer varies from case to case, with animal no. 234 (Fig. 9A) and animal no, 227 (Fig. 9C) being the least and most extensively labeled, respectively, and animal no. 228 (Fig. 9B) being intermediate.
Animal no. 227 received the most caudal injection in the IOC and animal no. 234 the most rostral one (Fig. 6).

Thus , the anterograde labeling in the cerebellum supports previous results ( Eisenman ' 81, ' 84 ) showing that lobules VIII and IX receive climbing fibers arising mainly from the caudal half of the IOC .

In animal no . 227, the almost complete staining of the contralateral vermis of lobules VIII and IX ( at the left in Fig . 9 ) suggests that complete filling of the molecular layer will occur given a large enough injection in the corresponding olive .
Crossing the midline from left to right, in all 3 animals there is first a weakly labeled zone and then a strongly labeled one, the latter at about 200-300 bm from the midline.

Despite the similarities in the staining patterns, comparison with adjacent sections reacted for the mabQ113 antigen revealed that the strongly labeled ipsilateral zones do not correspond to the a0 same mabQl13 territory in all 3 cases: in animal no. 234 the labeled band is congruent with the right P 1 territory ~ (this point is emphasized in Fig. 111, but in animals nos. 227 and 228, it corresponds to the P2+ territory (see also Fig. 10).
This situation exemplifies thc fact that interindividual comparisons of olivocerebellar projection are difficult when based solely on planimetric data collected from the cerebellar cortex .

For this reason, all subsequent cases shown in this paper concern comparisons of the anterograde pattern of olivocerebellar projection with the mabQl13 staining pattern between closely spaced sections (100 pn or less) taken from the same animal.
Comparison of olivocerebellar projection zones with
rnabQ113 imrnunohistochernical compartmentalization

Given that all regions of the cerebellar cortex are innervated by climbing fibers derived from the IOCs ( Desclin , ' 74 ; Courville and Faraco - Cantin , ' 74 ; Blatt and Eisenman , ' 85 ) , differential accumulation of ' the anterograde tracer in two adjacent zones of the cerebellar cortex is interpreted as resulting from the differential uptake of tracer by the groups of olivary cells projecting to each cortical zone .
This will occur when the projecting neurons in the olive are situated at unequal distances from the center of the injection site .
Conversely, adjacent regions of the cerebellar cortex will accumulate similar levels of tracer if the olivary regions projecting to them are contiguous (or if the whole TOC is saturated with tracer).
Consequently, adjacent zones of the cerebellar cortex displaying an abrupt change in the level of the tracer are interpreted as being innervated by noncontiguous olivary zones.
However, no similar conclusions can be drawn about the relative locations of olivary groups projecting to similarly stained cortical regions.

Therefore , when comparing the banding pattern resulting from an olivary injection of WGA - HRP with the banding pattern revealed immunocytochemically by mabQ113, the abrupt transitions observed in the tracer accumulation in the molecular layer of the cortex have been considered as indicative of the organization of the olivocerebellar projection , and this organization has been compared with the transition zones between mabQllS + and mabQ113Pur - kinje cells in the adjacent sections .
Figure 10A , B shows adjacent horizontal sections of lobules VIII and IX of animal no . 227 revealed for either anterograde transport of WGA - HRP by using TMB ( Fig .
lOAj, or for antigenic bands by using mabQll3 (Fig.
IOB).

Typically , for almost all boundaries between cortical regions containing high or low levels of the anterograde tracer ( arrowheads in Fig . lOA ) , a corresponding transition zone between mabQll3 - positive and mabQ113 - negative stretches of cerebellar cortex can be found ( arrowheads in Fig .
IOB).

The one consistent exception to this rule concerns the midline where the clear transition between high and low tracer accumulation passing from the contralateral to the ipsilateral cortex does not correlate with the boundary between a mabQ113+ and a mabQ113zone.
This is consistent with the idea, noted above, that the (rnabQ113S) P1+ band that straddles the midline is in fact two contiguous mabQ113 + bands, one in each hemicerebellum.

Starting in the cortex contralateral to the injection site ( left ) , at least two subtle transitions in the density of anterograde tracer in lobule VIII ( those between P1and P2 + , arrowheads ) have corresponding transitions in the mabQll3 staining pattern .
On the side ipsilateral to the injection site ( right ) , the boundaries of high and low accumulation of anterograde tracer in lobules VIII and IX correspond to the boundaries of the P2 + band .
Another example of concordance between the olivocerebellar and antigenic zonation in the vermis is shown in Figure 11A , B .

Again, in this animal (234) the boundaries of olivocerebellar projection zones (Fig. 11A) correspond to the similarly situated boundaries between rnabQ113 +/mabQ113zones seen on a closely spaced section (Fig. 11B).

In this particular case, the anatomical midline is not highlighted by a clear edge in the density of anterogradely transported material, and the cortical zones that correspond to the P1 + bands have accumulated only low levels of tracer.
On the left side of lobules VIII and IX , the zone of high tracer accumulation delineated by arrowheads corresponds to the territory of the P2 + band .
On the right side , however , the cortical region showing dense accumulation of tracer neareast the midline corresponds to the territory of the P1band .
Thus, as anticipated, parasagittal bands in the olivocerebellar projection can be situated in either a mabQ113 + or mabQll3 zone
~ same correspondence between olivocerebellar and antigenic zones can also be demonstrated in the cerebellar hemispheres .
Figure 12A-D shows parts of the hemispheres of animal no. 235 either contralateral (left panel) or ipsilateral (right panel) to the injection side.
Tracer accumulation can be found in the two sides ( A and C ) , but it is much stronger contralaterally .

As in the vermis , most of the clear boundaries between labeled and unlabeled bands in the olivocerebellar projection correspond to boundaries between positive and negative mabQ113 zones ( I3 and D ) .
In A, the most lateral transition zone between high and low levels of tracer (extreme left) corresponds in B to the medial edge of P5b+.
The more medial transition zone in the olivocerebellar projection pattern in A corresponds in a very precise manner to the lateral border of the P4a + band .
Finally , another transition boundary in the olivocerebellar projection , situated in the vermis ( extreme right of A ) , corresponds to the medial border of P4a + ( Fig . 12B ) .
In panel C , the arrowheads delineate a band of dense anterograde labeling that is exactly congruent with the P5bi band marked by arrowheads in D .
Finally , Figure 13 ( animal no . 234 ) provides a second example of the correspondence between olivocerebellar and antigenic zones in the hemispheres .
The three most rostra1 edges that are indicated by arrowheads in the olivocerebellar projection pattern in Figure 13A match the medial boundary of the P5b + band.
The lower thin band of high tracer accumulation marked in Figure 13A corresponds to the location of the P5a + band in B.

Moreover, comparing the patterns of olivocerebellar projections in Figures 12A and 13A emphasizes that striking similarities are seen between hemispheres after similar anterograde tracer injections in the IOC.

Discussion.S: DISCUSSION
MabQ113 recognizes an intracellular epitope expressed in a subpopulation of Purkinje cells that are aligned in parasagittal bands in the cerebellar cortex (Hawkes et al., '85).

The projection domains of various fiber afferents and the efferent Purkinje cell axons are also organized into parasagittally oriented zones in the cortex, so it is natural to ask how many organizational maps are represented in the cerebellum.

Although the Purkinje cell axons are the sole efferent projection from the cerebellar cortex, there are multiple afferent pathways, falling into two classes based on their modes of termination: the climbing fibers synapsing directly on Purkinje cells and the mossy fibers that contact the Purkinje cells indirectly via the granule cells, Mossy fibers originate from very diverse regions of the brain (reviewed in Bloedel and Courville, '81) and so bring in a wide variety of information to be processed; likewise the climbing fibers, although of homogenous origin, seem to convey information from different modalities to the cortex and these modalities can converge on relatively restricted regions of the cerebellar cortex, even if they come from widely different parts of the body (reviewed in Ito, '84).
Likewise, several studies with biochemical markers have concluded that multiple, overlapping zones are represented (Chan-Palay et al., '81,82; Nilaver et al., '82; Ingram et al., '85).
In consequence, there is no a priori basis for a unique organizational map of the cerebellum, and the existence of one or many maps has to be assessed empirically.
In particular, there are no studies in the rat that have delineated clearly a common plan for the mossy and climbing fiber afferents, or for afferents and the intrinsic molecular markers.
This task is technically complex and the problem may be more easily addressed by using mabQ113 bands as a constant and reproducible reference set.
We have started to answer this question by looking at the relationship between the topography of the climbing fiber projection and the topography of mabQ 113 expression.

We believe that bands are seen in the olivocerebellar projection primarily because, although the projection is completely filled and all Purkinje cells receive climbing fiber input, the map is discontinuous so that adjacent regions of the IOC do not necessarily project to adjacent regions of the cerebellar cortex.

For example, HRP-WGA tracer studies of the olivocerebellar projection to the uvula and pyramis of both the rat (Eisenman, '81,'84; Eisenman and Goracci, '83) and cat (reviewed in Brodal and Kawamura, '80) have shown that contiguous parasagittal bands in the cerebellar cortex can receive afferents from noncontiguous groups of olivary cells.

In this study, we reported that the climbing fiber projection from the inferior olive and the expression of the mabQ113 epitope seem to respect a common compartmentation, This is supported by the following observations: both patterns are arranged into parasagitally organized bands or patches in the cerebellar cortex; the two patterns are reproducible (to demonstrate this for the climbing fiber projection pattern requires that similar injections of anterograde tracer are achieved, e.g., nos. 274,275 in Fig, 12,13; there is a high level of concordance between the cortical localization of transition zones delineating discrete olivocerebellar projection territories and the location of transition zones between mabQ113 + and mabQ113 - cortical regions.

It remains to be determined whether every cluster of mabQ113 -t and mabQll3 - Purkinje cells receives afferent input from an individual, specific subgroup of olivary cells; that is, are there finer subdivisions in the olivocerebellar plan than are suggested by mabQ113 immunocytochemistry?
This will be more easily addressed by combining mabQ113 immunocytochemistry with the retrograde mapping of the olivocerebellar pathways.

Even though bands in the olivocerebellar projection seem to be coupled to bands of mabQ113 + and mabQll3 - immunoreactive Purkinje cells, the situation with respect to other molecular markers remains unclear given the several claims of overlapping antigenic Purkinje cell categories (Chan-Palay et al. '81,'82; Nilaver et al., '82; Ingram et al., '85).

One possible explanation is that the expression of some molecular markers is related to the dynamic metabolic state of the cell rather than to its permanent phenotype, a situation that could presage a distinction between topographically defined cerebellar compartments and functional units.

The one case in which the olivocerebellar topography and the mabQ113 +/ mabQ113 - boundaries do not correspond is at the midline, where the purely contralateral olivocerebellar projection splits the P1+ band.

In this special case it seems more probable that P1+ is, in fact, two confluent mabQ113+ bands, one in each hemisphere, in which case the agreement between mabQ113 and anterograde transport seems to be complete.
"he purely ipsilateral corticonuclear projection and our observations of Purkinje cell axon fasciculation at the midline both support this assertion.

Although a common plan relates the expression of the mabQ113 epitope and the olivocerebellar projection, the possibility of a causal link between the two Purkinje cell immunological phenotypes and the climbing fiber zonation is still unclear.
As already cited, it seems that all regions of the cerebellar cortex receive climbing fiber afferents and that the sole source of climbing fibers is the IOC.

Moreover, our results show that the labeled patches of molecular layer obtained following injection of an anterograde tracer in the inferior olive can share boundaries with either a mabQ113+ of mabQll3zone.
So it is clear that the pattern of positive and negative immunoreactive Purkinje cells is not caused by the presence or absence of climbing fibers innervating the cells composing these bands.

Likewise, although the nature of the epitope recognized by mabQ113 is still poorly understood, its intracellular location (Hawkes et al., '85) and late appearance during Purkinje cell development (Hawkes and Leclerc, '85) make it an unlikely candidate as a cell recognition molecule for ingrowing climbing fibers during development.
The possibility remains that there exist two different populations of climbing fibers, one projecting to mabQll3 + bands, the other to mabQ113 - bands.

Marani et al. ('77) have shown in the cat a differential staining pattern for acetylcholinesterase in the inferior olive and have suggested that this is in relation with the pattern of parasagittally oriented bands of Ache staining seen in the cerebellar cortex of kittens (Ramon-Moliner, '72; Marani and Voogd, '77; Marani, '82) and adult cats (Brown and Graybiel, '83).
Both anatomical (Sotelo et al., '74) and physiological Glinas et al., '74) studies have shown electrotonical coupling between cells of the IOC.

Simultaneous recording from multiple Purkinje cells in the cerebellar cortex reveals spontaneous synchrony of complex spikes in rostrocaudal stretches (Bower and Llinris, '83; Sasaki and Llinas, '85).

Administration of picrotoxin leads to the mediolateral spread of the synchrony, which suggests that gamma-aminobutyric-acid (GABA)-mediated inhibition can modulate electrotonic coupling between precise sets of IOC cells projecting to distinct parasagittal zones (Sasaki and Llinas, '85).
Recently, Sotelo et al. ('86) have provided an anatomical substrate for the modulatory role of GABA inhibition in the spatial organization of olivary firing.
These "physiological subpopulations" of IOC cells may correspond to the "topographical subpopulations" implicit in our results.

It remains to be determined whether the expression of the mabQ113 antigen is sustained or induced by climbing fibers or other afferent cues, or if the mabQ113 phenotype is intrinsic to two different populations of Purkinje cells.
